<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_softirq_allocate:
```c
int metal_softirq_allocate(int num)
{
	int irq_base;

	if ((metal_softirq_avail + num) >= metal_softirq_num) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "No more available soft irqs\n");
		return -EINVAL;
	}
	irq_base = metal_softirq_avail;
	irq_base += metal_softirq_cntr.irq_base;
	metal_softirq_avail += num;
	return irq_base;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function metal_softirq_allocate:
#define metal_log(level, fmt, __VA_ARGS__) ({if(_metal.common.log_handler&&level<=_metal.common.log_level)_metal.common.log_handler(level,metal_fmt(fmt),##__VA_ARGS__);\
})
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
#define metal_log(level, fmt, __VA_ARGS__) ({if(_metal.common.log_handler&&level<=_metal.common.log_level)_metal.common.log_handler(level,metal_fmt(fmt),##__VA_ARGS__);\
})
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.2 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The macro metal_log expands to a call through the function pointer _metal.common.log_handler and does not itself define or call the enclosing function. As written there is no direct or implicit self-call, so the fragment does not by itself violate Rule 17.2. However, an indirect recursion scenario that would violate Rule 17.2 is possible if the log_handler is set to a function that calls metal_log (or otherwise ends up calling the same handler). Example: void my_log(int lvl, const char *fmt, ...) { /* ... */ metal_log(lvl, fmt, ...); } _metal.common.log_handler = my_log; Then metal_log -> _metal.common.log_handler (my_log) -> metal_log ... which is indirect recursion and would violate Rule 17.2.
